{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3575546,"name":null,"username":"Jon_S79","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jon_s79/{size}/257714_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-31T22:08:49.643Z","cooked":"

Hi! I was wondering if anyone had a system of teaching Electrical FRC. Currently trying to build a curriculum for our team for next year.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-03-31T22:08:49.643Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":26,"reads":265,"readers_count":264,"score":243.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":497588,"topic_slug":"teaching-electrical","display_username":null,"primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":70976,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Assistant Electrical Lead"},"post_url":"/t/teaching-electrical/497588/1","custom_user_title":"Assistant Electrical Lead","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3575626,"name":"","username":"FinIce","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/finice/{size}/270519_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-31T23:17:11.591Z","cooked":"

What we typically do is run through a components list every once in a while, plus do practical exams using older robots, having members trace and identify what is used for what purposes on them. During this we also explain what things do, what is needed for them, and answer questions.

In addition, we run through many of the major connectors, basic practices, and skills that are needed for Electrical, drawing from our Electrical Manual for instructions on each process.

“I do, we do, you do” everywhere.

Using that strategy, just teach everyone the fundamentals first:

  • what each wire does
  • crimping (ferrules, powerpole, etc)
  • soldering
  • routing
  • using cable track/loom
  • reinforcement/protection

From that point on start combining things into little mini projects and gradually expand into wiring full robots; ideally every electrical student should be able to wire an entire robot by themselves, but this is of course not necessarily needed.

Here is a link to two training resources we did for our teams four years ago.

Generally, making a kitbot or Everybot has been great for training rookies on electrical and seeing results. The electrical guide for the Everybot is pretty great which links to a 24 minute electrical video that FIRST made and the Intro to FRC Wiring by WPILib. Between those 3 resources and what others have said are pretty good places to start.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-04-01T13:52:59.378Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":123,"readers_count":122,"score":69.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":497588,"topic_slug":"teaching-electrical","display_username":"The Imagery Queen","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://robonauts-everybot.github.io/Everybot-Docs/manual/electronics","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Everybot Electrical | Everybot Docs","clicks":9},{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lGgIhxYuSHM","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":5},{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/zero-to-robot/step-1/intro-to-frc-robot-wiring.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Introduction to FRC Robot Wiring — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":4}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30242,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"The Imagery Queen"},"post_url":"/t/teaching-electrical/497588/5","custom_user_title":"The Imagery Queen","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3576793,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-01T17:18:56.057Z","cooked":"

We have over 100 student members so we select from returning team members for groups like electrical, running the CNC router and building, drive team and maintaining swerve modules. The selection criterial are being teachable, dedication, attention to detail, and quality of work. We have been burnt by investing time and energy to train someone then finding out they stop showing up.

I have found some people are better suited to this kind of work because they have better attention to detail and better fine motor skills. Unfortunately, I have not found a way to teach these skills/abilities after many years of trying.

We teach the members of the electrical group the same stuff that @crueter listed. We also require them to learn CAD (OnShape) so they can be involved in the design of the robot to prevent the control system from being an afterthought. They do the placement of the electrical components and pre-plan wire routing paths. They also design the mounting panels so they can be cut on the CNC router.

This next summer, we are planning to add training relating to the functions of each pat of each component and training for how to do troubleshooting such as the “5 Why’s” method. I have noticed that many students can identify the components but don’t actually understand what they do so they are just guessing when troubleshooting.
